history.content: 170/12[0,6,7] are pretty foundational and good to take early. I would beware of stacking multiple project/lab classes like 162, 106A/B, 192, etc (you may want to narrow your focus).

children.subject:
Maybe. On the one hand, it's 12 units, but on the other, 106B was easily the most time-consuming class I have taken (nevertheless, I recommend).

Also, you may want to consider grad classes eventually. Have not taken 149/192, but my understanding is that they treat robotics at a lower level of abstraction (relative to 106B), which may or may not be what you're looking for.
Got it. Seems like it will be good to ask the professors and listen to their description of EE149/192 and EECS 106A/B to see the difference. Thank you!
Do you think Spring 2022 is a little bit too much?

My interest is to take a specialized role to build human-interactive robots (interested in HRI). More specifically, I want to build robots that act upon human gestures, facial expressions, or human voice. That's why I plan to do both Robotics and AI. I feel so happy building robots. At the same time, my dream is to make robots more accessible to humanity.

Research looks cool, but I am more interested in conducting projects so I can come up with an actual product.

Currently, I find Google X's project "Everyday Robot Project" really interesting, and presume HRI will be useful in that project. I am also a huge fan of Boston Dynamics, but I'm not sure if they do HRI focused projects. I gotta admit that I don't really know much about robotics industry yet. Hope this paragraph answers to your initial question of what my ultimate goal in robotics & AI is. I really do appreciate your comment!

Ok I don't think you should discount research so early as there are a few professors here that are involved with the actual design of robotics; look at the work that Professor Goldberg's is doing and you might find something similar to what you want, and also check out various other labs like Professor Tomlin and Professor Sastry. There are plenty of very famous people within robotics and even if they don't do exactly what you want, conducting research within their groups will open a lot of doors for you. 

Although take anything I say with a grain of salt since robotics is not the field I'm most involved with, but the best option would probably be take 128 as soon as possible, and courses like 126 and 127 are more essential for machine learning (and to a much lesser extent deep learning and neural networks). I'm of the opinion that 182 is not very useful unless you want to focus on deep learning specifically, rather than AI in general.

What you should really do though, is ignore all advice you get here on piazza, and email one of the aforementioned professors (or maybe one of their grad students since they might be more receptive of your emails) and ask them about what are the best courses to take for what you are in interested in.

TLDR: Look at some of the professor that do robotics research, see if it interests you, talk to them/their grad students on what to take, but IMO in order of roughly decreasing importance  (take with a grain of salt) 128, 170,  221A, 126, 127, 226 (very uncertain where to put this one), 189, 182. Note that 106 goes somewhere in there, likely above 126/127 but I don't know enough about it to properly judge (although my knowledge of 128 and 221A is not that great either)

The real question is what is your ultimate goal in robotics and AI? Is it to find a job, even a software engineering role, within a company that deals with robotics or AI? Is it to do a more specialized role than just general software engineering? Or is it to conduct independent research within the field(s)? The best schedule of courses changes depending on what you wish to do.

history.content:
Hi. Current EECS sophomore student here. I am trying to figure out which courses to take for next 2.5 years. I heard there are some combinations of courses I need to avoid. Could you see my plan for next 5 semesters and give me a heads up if there is a bad combination of courses (too intense workload, you gotta take this after/before this class, take this course instead of that, etc)?

I am interested in Robotics + AI. I was trying to double IEOR and EECS, but later decided to just take EECS only.

What I took:

Math 53, Math 54, Physics 7B, CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 70, EE 16A, R1A, R1B, E7, E120, IEOR 162

Plan 1:

Plan 2:

Plan 3:

*I will take CS61C this summer. 

Thank you for the advice!
